awd_titl_txt: Role of histone variant H3.3 in DNA repair
awd_abstract_narration:
Histone proteins wrap DNA around themselves to form filaments called chromosomes, thereby regulating all aspects of DNA function, including DNA repair. Chromosome structure in turn is regulated by posttranslational modifications (PTMs) on the histones and the use of primary sequence variants of the canonical histones. Unlike its canonical counterparts, the histone variant H3.3 is deposited throughout the cell cycle in transcriptionally active regions, where it forms unstable nucleosomes. The research will examine a new potential role for H3.3 in DNA repair. The research will benefit society by promoting science education and training future scientists, while contributing to a better understanding of how histone proteins promote DNA repair. This research will be carried out with the involvement of K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students as well as postdoctoral scholars and will have a broad impact on science education and the training of future scientists. Early exposure to the joys of science encourages students to pursue future careers in science. Through a college-based summer outreach program, rural and minority K-12 students will be exposed to research concepts in the PIs lab. Genetic model systems such as the budding yeast and fruit flies are ideal for educating K-12 (and undergraduate) students in the methods of scientific research and explaining genetic principles. The PI will also continue to host high school juniors in his lab each summer under the Young Scholars Program (YSP) as they work on mini-projects. These mini-projects usually perform very well at science competitions, which helps them secure admission and scholarships at top universities. 

While the transcriptional roles of histone H3.3 are well known, recent evidence also suggests critical transcription independent roles of H3.3. Consistent with this evidence, preliminary data pointing to a crucial role for H3.3 in homologous recombination (HR)-mediated DNA repair has been obtained, and this project will investigate the molecular mechanisms involved. The specific hypothesis to be tested is that histone H3.3 and its PTMs modulate chromatin structure at DNA damage sites to help recruit HR repair factors, thereby contributing to genomic integrity. The hypothesis will be tested by (i) determining the role of H3.3 in HR mediated DNA repair in distinct chromatin structures, (ii) identifying its DNA repair specific chaperones, and (iii) defining the role of H3.3 modifications in DNA repair. The research will use genome sequencing based biochemical assays, live cell microscopy, and mass spectrometry (MS) to determine the role of H3.3 and its modifications in HR-mediated DNA repair. The analyses will be carried out primarily in normal and H3.3 deficient cultured human cells, as well as in patient derived tumor cell lines carrying H3.3 mutations. A potentially useful byproduct of the MS data generated during the course of this research is the identification of novel DNA damage inducible PTMs on histones other than H3.3. Hence, the findings from this research will establish the role for H3.3 in DNA repair and will also lay the groundwork for the functional analysis of other histone variants implicated in DNA repair. Furthermore, due to the evolutionary conservation of the major processes involving chromatin and DNA repair, the research will yield useful information on mechanisms that contribute to genomic stability across eukaryotic species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The histone family of proteins help wrap DNA around themselves to fit it inside the nucleus of our cells. Histone proteins come in different flavors that differ slightly from each other and help regulate how and when genes are turned on and off depending on the individual’s needs. One such histone protein is called H3.3, which is mutated in the vast majority of the 100% fatal childhood brain tumors known as Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG), as well as in specific types of bone and cartilage tumors found predominantly in children and young adults. How mutations in H3.3 cause cancer and why they occur primarily in children is unclear, although it has been suggested that this may be due to aberrant regulation of genes by mutant H3.3, or due to an impact on the cellular DNA repair processes. Our DNA is constantly incurring DNA damage such as breaks in the DNA and relies on a handful of dedicated DNA repair mechanisms to detect and fix them. The precise role of H3.3 in DNA repair is currently unclear. Using the funds provided by the NSF, we have been studying the role of H3.3 in DNA repair in great detail over the past 4 years. Our results show a clear role for H3.3 in repairing DNA breaks by the highly accurate pathway known as Homologous Recombination (HR). The role H3.3 in repairing DNA may be particularly important in areas known as heterochromatin where the DNA is densely packaged and difficult to access by the repair machinery. Deficiency of H3.3 therefore results in cells relying on the more error-prone and mutation-causing Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ) DNA break repair pathways. Hence, additional mutations would accumulate faster in H3.3 mutant cells that are defective in accurate DNA repair, eventually leading to cancer. This may explain why H3.3 mutant cancers occur predominantly at a young age. Additionally, we provide evidence that H3.3 is likely functioning as a novel HR promoting “DNA repair pathway choice factor” by preventing the binding of another histone known as H1 that is known to promote DNA repair by NHEJ. Most importantly, our studies have revealed potential therapies for treating the currently incurable H3.3 mutant childhood brain tumors.

Broader Impacts: Overall, during the course of the grant, a total of 25 students at various levels were mentored by our lab. Eleven (44%) out of the 25 trainees were women and several of the trainees identify as underrepresented minorities. These trainees include 2 Ph.D. students (including one African American), 10 undergraduates and 8 high school students, all of whom were trained in our lab. An additional 5 high school students were mentored online during the pandemic. About ~2 dozen high school students, including many from rural areas of Florida, were also exposed to research in our lab through the SSTRIDE (Science Students Together Reaching Instructional Diversity & Excellence) Summer Institute outreach program of the Florida State University College of Medicine (FSU CoM). The training provided to graduate, undergraduate and high school students will certainly have a broad impact in the future when these trainees graduate and go into science related careers as they join the workforce. In fact, three of the undergraduates who trained in the lab using the funds provided have already started medical school, while two of the high school students trained in the lab have secured admissions in top tier colleges and plan to major in science related areas. Furthermore, given that several of the trainees are women or minorities who currently show an interest in a career in academic research, in the future at least some of them are likely to be involved in training the next generation of exceptional scientific minds. Last but not least, our research findings have suggested potential therapies for the currently incurable H3.3 mutant brain tumors, which may have an impact in treating such patients in the clinic one day.
